item.title: Using the System timer instead of 'processing' them
item.dc:creator: @Tree_Climber Tree_Climber
item.description:
@Tree_Climber wrote:

[quote=“m.dog311, post:15, topic:275922”]There’s a much better way to do all this.

Read
http://www.java2s.com/Code/Java/Development-Class/UsejavautilTimertoscheduleatasktoexecuteonce5secondshavepassed.htm
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/Timer.html
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/TimerTask.html[/quote]
or a ScheduledExecutorService.
Although checking for past time this is the right way to do it.
@OP: You sir, deserve a cookie.[br][br][size=1]Posted on: August 24, 2009, 09:16:21 pm[/size][hr][quote=“new IoSession();, post:16, topic:275922”][quote author=m.dog311 link=topic=364462.msg2768298#msg2768298 date=1240955144]
There’s a much better way to do all this.

Read
http://www.java2s.com/Code/Java/Development-Class/UsejavautilTimertoscheduleatasktoexecuteonce5secondshavepassed.htm
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/Timer.html
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/TimerTask.html
[/quote]

java.util.TimerTask runs on a single thread. Everytime you make a new timing task, A new thread is created.

What you simply could do is write your own event system.[/quote]
Nope, Sun isn’t a bunch of fucking morons, they wouldn’t write shitty inefficient code like that.
java.util.Timer creates a new thread to execute tasks.

Read full topic

Which was from stork's varekd, which was from the original RSCD team, which i'll guess Sean wrote the delayed event handler.

item.source: Using the System timer instead of 'processing' them

item.title: Using the System timer instead of 'processing' them
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

Nice tutorial, this is better than those dum Util Timers, so thanks.

No, this is different than those “dumb util timers”.
The [tt]java.util.Timer[/tt] class allows you to execute certain code after a certain delay at a set time interval.
This kind of timer prevents you from performing an action more than once before a certain amount of time has passed.

An event manager would be better than both, however.

Read full topic

item.title: Using the System timer instead of 'processing' them
item.dc:creator: @Zach_93 Zach 93
item.description:
@Zach_93 wrote:

[quote=“m.dog311, post:15, topic:275922”]There’s a much better way to do all this.

Read
http://www.java2s.com/Code/Java/Development-Class/UsejavautilTimertoscheduleatasktoexecuteonce5secondshavepassed.htm
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/Timer.html
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/TimerTask.html[/quote]

This delays an action, not sets a delay on it’s ability to perform.

For example, a good usage for the Timer class would be damage delays. Because they’re always going to happen after the weapon is swung. The player doesn’t always have to click an object every five seconds though, which is what the Timer would do.

And what the above said as well, you’ll find that the only decent 508 server base, rs2hd, uses an event manager.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @new_IoSession new IoSession();
item.description:
@new_IoSession wrote:

[quote=“m.dog311, post:15, topic:275922”]There’s a much better way to do all this.

Read
http://www.java2s.com/Code/Java/Development-Class/UsejavautilTimertoscheduleatasktoexecuteonce5secondshavepassed.htm
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/Timer.html
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/api/java/util/TimerTask.html[/quote]

java.util.TimerTask runs on a single thread. Everytime you make a new timing task, A new thread is created.

What you simply could do is write your own event system.

Thanks Chassy.

Is it me or are quotes not working?

[quote][/quote]

Did you use that?

@Topic: Nice, but couldn’t you use a short rather than an int?

He’s using a long, and it’s the only primitive data type that can use System.currentTimeMillis().
[/quote]

Hmm it can only be used by the long datatype … ?

int i = (int)System.currentTimeMillis() / 1000;

Oh wait you must not have learned about casting![/quote]

Obviously I haven’t; thanks for correcting me.

item.source: Using the System timer instead of 'processing' them

item.title: Using the System timer instead of 'processing' them
item.dc:creator: @primadude Primadude
item.description:
@primadude wrote:

Hey everyone, today I am going to teach you how to use ‘timers’ more efficiently by using the system’s current millisecond time. It can be used in codes in which you want to restrict something being done in a certain amount of time.

Everyday I see tutorials/servers containing codes in the process method to restrict something from happening, such as the delay in which you are able to eat a food item/drink a potion. There is a much efficient way to do it: the System timer.

The ‘System.currentTimeMillis’ is a long datatype and is equal to the current time in milliseconds. The long data type is a 64-bit datatype, and it is used when you want to have a larger scale of number(s), instead of an int.

If, for example, you wanted to restrict players using an object for … let’s say 10 seconds, you would do this:

[code]long integer;

if (objectID == ####) {
if (System.currentTimeMillis() - integer < 10000) {
sendMessage(“You can only use this object once every 10 seconds.”);
return;
}
integer = System.currentTimeMillis();
/*
* Whatever the object does goes here.
*/
}[/code]

10000 milliseconds is equal to 10 seconds, hence the “integer < 10000”.
The long variable will equal to the current system’s time in milliseconds if 10 seconds have passed - Remember this. The system’s current time will constantly be raising while the ‘integer’ variable will not, until 10000 milliseconds (10 seconds) have passed, then it will be equalled to the system’s time again.

The System’s time is constantly going up in milliseconds, just like the real world time.

if (System.currentTimeMillis() - integer < 10000) {

This line means that if the System’s current time minus the ‘integer’ variable (which was equalled to the system’s time), does not exceed 10000 milliseconds, then you cannot gain what the object does/gives to the character until it does exceed 10000 milliseconds, and the method will end by using the ‘return;’ code.

As I said at the beginning, it can also be used for food item eating. Here is an example of that:

[code]case 385:
long healTimer;

if (System.currentTimeMillis() - healTimer >= 2000) {
	healTimer = System.currentTimeMillis();
	deleteItem(385, Slot, 1);
	startAnimation(829);
	updateHp(20, true);
}
break;[/code]

For this food item (Shark) you have to wait 2000 milliseconds (2 seconds) in between eating each one.

I hope you all learned something ;).
If you feel I have missed anything post a reply, or PM me :).

Read full topic
item.source: Using the System timer instead of 'processing' them
